{{Infobox Military Memorial |name = Spanish–American War Memorial |image = [[File:Spanish-American War Memorial - looking NW at column - Arlington National Cemetery - 2011.JPG|250px]] |caption = The Spanish–American War Memorial in 2011 |country = United States |commemorates = those American military personnel who died in the [[Spanish–American War]] |unveiled = {{start date and age|1902|05|12}} |coordinates = {{Coord|38.875374|-77.074544|type:landmark_region:GB-WSM|display=inline,title}} |nearest_town = [[Arlington County, Virginia]], [[United States|U.S.]] }} The '''Spanish–American War Memorial''' is a [[memorial]] in [[Arlington National Cemetery]] in [[Arlington County, Virginia]], in the United States that commemorates those American military personnel who died in the [[Spanish–American War]]. Constructed by the [[National Society of the Colonial Dames of America]] and dedicated on May 21, 1902, the memorial consists of a [[granite]] [[column]] in the center of a small grass-covered plaza. A granite sphere and bronze eagle with outstretched wings stand atop the shaft. The memorial faces west; to its rear across Lawton Avenue is a [[flagstone]] [[Terrace (building)|terrace]] on which are placed four cannon, aimed east.
==Spanish–American War dead at Arlington National Cemetery== The Spanish–American War was a ten-week conflict that occurred in the spring and summer of 1898. [[Cuba]] had been [[Cuban War of Independence|waging a war of independence]] against [[Spain]] since 1895, an effort largely supported by the United States (which had extensive economic interests on the island). To ensure the safety of American citizens and property in Cuba, the United States sent the [[battleship]] {{USS|Maine|ACR-1}} to [[Havana]] in late January 1898. The ''Maine'' exploded under mysterious circumstances and was destroyed with large loss of life on February 15. American newspapers [[Propaganda of the Spanish–American War|whipped up war fever]], and held Spain responsible for the ship's destruction. The [[United States Congress]] enacted a [[joint resolution]] demanding independence for Cuba, and President [[William McKinley]] signed it into law on April 20. In response, Spain severed [[Diplomacy|diplomatic relations]] on April 21. The same day, the [[United States Navy]] began a [[blockade]] of Cuba. Spain [[Declaration of war|declared war]] on April 23. On April 25, Congress declared that a state of war between the U.S. and Spain had existed since April 21.<ref>Trask, p. 57.</ref>
The Spanish–American War began on April 25, 1898, and ended on August 12, 1898. Cuban and Spanish dead vastly outnumbered American deaths. While 2,910 American military personnel died during the war, just 345 were combat deaths. The rest died of disease.<ref>Dyal, Carpenter, and Thomas, p. 67.</ref> More than 1,800 Americans were buried in Cuba, [[Hawaii]], the [[Philippines]], and [[Puerto Rico]]. On July 8, 1898, Congress enacted legislation authorizing the repatriation of American dead, and appropriating funds for this purpose. Additional legislation was enacted on February 9, 1900; May 26, 1900; and June 6, 1900. Many of the dead were buried at Arlington National Cemetery, either because their families desired it or the remains could not be identified. Of the dead, 226 were disinterred in Cuba, 20 from Puerto Rico, and 24 from Hawaii.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=NSkKAAAAIAAJ&dq=%22Arlington%20National%20Cemetery%22%20santiago%20burials&pg=PA82#v=onepage&q&f=false Quartermaster Corps, p. 82-84.] Accessed 2013-06-11.</ref> This represented the first time in history that Americans who died in battle overseas were repatriated to the United States for burial.<ref>Bigler, p. 46.</ref> Most of the military dead were buried in what is now Section 22, while members of the [[Rough Riders]] (or 1st United States Volunteer Cavalry) were buried in Section 23.<ref>Hinkel, p. 124.</ref> Civilian nurses (all of whom died of diease) were buried in what is now Section 21.<ref>Gurney, p. 70.</ref>
==First Spanish–American War Memorial== [[File:Spanish-American War Memorial - four cannon and plaza - Arlington National Cemetery - 2011.JPG|thumb|left|The four cannon at the Spanish–American War Memorial.]] Some time in early 1900, four guns captured during the war were erected in the Spanish–American War dead burial field.<ref name="WarReports">[https://books.google.com/books?id=lr9MAAAAYAAJ&dq=Maine%20%22Arlington%20National%20Cemetery%22%20anchor&pg=PA300#v=onepage&q=Maine%20%22Arlington%20National%20Cemetery%22%20anchor&f=false ''Annual Reports of the War Department for the Fiscal Year Ended June 30, 1900'', p. 300.] Accessed 2013-05-20.</ref> The two modern guns were taken from the [[Spanish Navy]] [[armored cruiser]]s ''[[Spanish cruiser Vizcaya|Vizcaya]]'' and ''[[Spanish cruiser Infanta Maria Teresa|Infanta Maria Teresa]]''.<ref name="Independent">[https://books.google.com/books?id=kTUxAQAAMAAJ&dq=%22Colonial%20Dames%22%20arlington&pg=PA1269#v=onepage&q&f=false "Survey of the World." ''The Independent.'' May 29, 1902, p. 1269.] Accessed 2013-06-11.</ref><ref name="Fame">"Fame of War Heroes." ''Washington Post.'' May 22, 1902.</ref> The provenance of the two smaller bronze cannon is less clear. One newspaper of the day said they came from a Spanish coastal battery in Cuba (which the paper did not identify),<ref name="Independent" /> but the ''[[The Washington Post|Washington Post]]'' was more specific and said they came from a coastal battery near [[Castillo de San Pedro de la Roca]] (also known as "Morro Castle") at [[Sevilla, Santiago de Cuba|Sevilla]] near [[Santiago de Cuba]].<ref name="Fame" /><ref name="NoMemorial">"No Memorial Shaft." ''Washington Post''. April 26, 1900.</ref><ref>The Arlington National Cemetery Web site claims the two bronze cannon were captured from Spain, but does not say where they were captured. The Web site claims the two modern guns belonged to the United States Navy, but other sources noted herein disagree with this. See: [http://www.arlingtoncemetery.mil/VisitorInformation/MonumentMemorials/SpanAmerican.aspx "Spanish-American War Monument." Monuments and Memorials. Exploring the Cemetery. Visitor Information. Arlington National Cemetery. No date.] Accessed 2013-06-13.</ref> All four guns were mounted on granite pedestals. The bronze cannon were [[Touch hole#Spiking the guns|spiked]], while the modern guns had their [[breechblock]]s removed.<ref name="NoMemorial" />
No trees were immediately planted around the site, leaving it barren but also visible from the [[Potomac River]].<ref name="NoMemorial" />
==The Second Spanish–American War Memorial==
===The Capron effort=== In February or March 1899, as Sections 21, 22, and 23 were being prepared for the burial of Spanish–American War dead, [[United States Secretary of War|Secretary of War]] [[Elihu Root]] chose a [[promontory]] on the eastern edge of the burial field as the site for a new Spanish–American War memorial. Veterans of the war strongly supported the construction of a memorial, but no action was taken. Agnes Kissam Capron, wife of [[Captain (United States)|Captain]] [[Allyn K. Capron, Sr.]] (an Army artillery officer who died of [[typhoid fever]] in September 1898), began lobbying Congress in April 1900 to appropriate money for a memorial<ref name="NoMemorial" /> and [[United States House of Representatives|Representative]] [[John H. Ketcham]] introduced H.R. 11091 to authorize it.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=UFYUAAAAYAAJ&dq=%22Spanish-American%20War%20Monument%22%20Arlington&pg=RA1-PA58#v=onepage&q&f=false "History of Bills and Joint Resolutions", p. 58.] Accessed 2013-06-11.</ref>
But Mrs. Capron left for the Philippines to engage in [[American Red Cross|Red Cross]] work shortly after her lobbying effort began,<ref name="NoMemorial" /> and no action was taken by Congress.
===National Society of Colonial Dames effort=== At its April 1900 National Council meeting in [[Washington, D.C.]], the National Society of the Colonial Dames of America voted to seek to place a memorial to Spanish–American War dead at Arlington National Cemetery. The genesis of this effort is unclear, but a committee to consider "the subject of a tablet at Arlington in memory of the officers, soldiers, and sailors of the Spanish–American War" was appointed some time prior to the biennial National Council meeting.<ref name="Dames80">[https://books.google.com/books?id=82EUAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA2-PA59&dq=%22Colonial+Dames%22+arlington&hl=en&sa=X&ei=xq63Ubb1CMTE0AGWiICYCQ&ved=0CEAQ6AEwAzgU#v=onepage&q=memorial&f=false National Society of The Colonial Dames of America, 1900, p. 80.] Accessed 2013-06-12.</ref> Winifred Lee Brent Lyster, wife of Dr. Henry Francis LeHunte Lyster of Michigan and a relative of [[Confederate States Army|Confederate Army]] [[General officers in the Confederate States Army#General (Full general)|General]] [[Robert E. Lee]],<ref name="BostonEvening" /> conceived of and was the primary advocate for the memorial.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=82EUAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA2-PA59&dq=%22Colonial+Dames%22+arlington&hl=en&sa=X&ei=xq63Ubb1CMTE0AGWiICYCQ&ved=0CEAQ6AEwAzgU#v=onepage&q=memorial&f=false National Society of The Colonial Dames of America, 1902, p. 29-31.] Accessed 2013-06-12.</ref><ref>Dr. Lyster joined the [[5th Michigan Volunteer Infantry Regiment]] at the outset of the [[American Civil War]] and rose through the ranks to become Medical Inspector and Acting Medical Director of [[III Corps (Union Army)|III Corps]] in the Union Army. He served from the [[First Battle of Bull Run]] to the [[Battle of Appomattox Court House]]. Mrs. Lyster wrote the popular song ''[[Michigan, My Michigan]]'' in late 1862, which later became the unofficial state song. See: [https://books.google.com/books?id=UBbiAAAAMAAJ&lpg=PA2238&ots=LzF7ZHeby6&dq=Henry%20F.%20LeHunte%20Lyster&pg=PA2238#v=onepage&q&f=false Moore, p. 2238-2241.] Accessed 2013-06-12.</ref> The Memorial Committee proposed a bronze tablet bearing the name of all those who died (from whatever cause) during the war, and that this tablet be erected before the National Council meeting in May 1902.<ref name="Dames80" /> The National Council approved a motion to have a tablet erected, but left the design and content up to a committee (to be appointed by the chair), which was given the power to act on the resolution.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=82EUAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA2-PA59&dq=%22Colonial+Dames%22+arlington&hl=en&sa=X&ei=xq63Ubb1CMTE0AGWiICYCQ&ved=0CEAQ6AEwAzgU#v=onepage&q=memorial&f=false National Society of The Colonial Dames of America, 1900, p. 80-81], accessed 2013-06-12; [http://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=loc.ark:/13960/t73t9zp0w;view=1up;seq=97 National Society of the Colonial Dames of America, 1913, p. 95], accessed 2013-06-12.</ref>
===Fundraising, design, and site selection=== [[File:Richard-Watson-Gilder.jpg|thumb|Richard Watson Gilder.]] Lyster was appointed chair of the society's Spanish War Memorial Committee.<ref name="Dames80" /> She wrote more than 2,000 letters asking for funds for the memorial.<ref name="Dames30">[https://books.google.com/books?id=82EUAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA2-PA59&dq=%22Colonial+Dames%22+arlington&hl=en&sa=X&ei=xq63Ubb1CMTE0AGWiICYCQ&ved=0CEAQ6AEwAzgU#v=onepage&q=memorial&f=false National Society of The Colonial Dames of America, 1902, p. 30.] Accessed 2013-06-12.</ref> Almost $7,300 (${{formatnum:{{inflation|US|7300|1902}}}} in {{CURRENTYEAR}} dollars) was raised.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=82EUAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA2-PA59&dq=%22Colonial+Dames%22+arlington&hl=en&sa=X&ei=xq63Ubb1CMTE0AGWiICYCQ&ved=0CEAQ6AEwAzgU#v=onepage&q=memorial&f=false National Society of The Colonial Dames of America, 1902, p. 13-14.] Accessed 2013-06-12.</ref>
Choosing a site for the memorial was not difficult. The [[Quartermaster Corps (United States Army)|Army Quartermaster Corps]] controlled Arlington National Cemetery, and in March 1901 Lyster asked the [[Quartermaster General of the United States Army|Quartermaster General]], [[Brigadier general (United States)|Brigadier General]] [[Marshall I. Ludington]], for permission to erect the memorial at Arlington National Cemetery.<ref name="ArlingtonNational" /> Permission was granted, provided the federal government bore none of the cost.<ref name="ArlingtonNational" /> It is unclear just when the society obtained the pre-determined 1899 site, however. The Secretary of War had chosen the site in early 1899, and the existing memorial was already located there. Obtaining the site for the Society memorial was not a foregone conclusion. The record is clear, however, that Justine Van Rensselaer Townsend,<ref>She was the wife of [[Albany Medical College]] professor Dr. [[Howard Townsend]], and the granddaughter of billionaire [[New York (state)|New York]] landowner [[Stephen Van Rensselaer III]].</ref> President of the National Society of Colonial Dames, approached Secretary of the War Root directly and secured the existing location for the Society's memorial.<ref name="BostonEvening">[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=yJo-AAAAIBAJ&sjid=bloMAAAAIBAJ&dq=colonial%20dames%20arlington%20cemetery%20memorial&pg=6610%2C3094723 "Spanish War Memorial." ''Boston Evening Transcript.'' May 22, 1902, p. 3.] Accessed 2013-06-12.</ref><ref name="Dames50">[https://books.google.com/books?id=82EUAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA2-PA59&dq=%22Colonial+Dames%22+arlington&hl=en&sa=X&ei=xq63Ubb1CMTE0AGWiICYCQ&ved=0CEAQ6AEwAzgU#v=onepage&q=memorial&f=false National Society of The Colonial Dames of America, 1902, p. 50.] Accessed 2013-06-12.</ref>
A Committee on Estimates and Designs, a subcommittee of the Spanish War Memorial Committee, was established to oversee the design of the memorial.<ref name="Dames50" /> The process by which designs were solicited and chosen is not clear. However, the winning design was submitted by Society member Edith Bucklin Hartshorn Mason of Rhode Island.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=82EUAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA2-PA59&dq=%22Colonial+Dames%22+arlington&hl=en&sa=X&ei=xq63Ubb1CMTE0AGWiICYCQ&ved=0CEAQ6AEwAzgU#v=onepage&q=memorial&f=false National Society of the Colonial Dames of America, 1906, p. 34.] Accessed 2013-06-12.</ref> The National Society of Colonial Dames was required to obtain the consent of the Quartermaster Corps for the memorial's design. Major Theodore A. True, an officer in the [[Signal Corps (United States Army)|U.S. Army Signal Corps]] at [[Fort Myer]], served as the representative of the Quartermaster General at the cemetery. True expressed concern over the original design. The design was changed and resubmitted several times before it met with True's approval. True submitted the final draft design to Brigadier General Ludington. Ludington approved it and forwarded it to Secretary of War Elihu Root. Root confirmed True and Ludington's decision and on October 23, 1901, informed the Society that it could erect its memorial.<ref name="ArlingtonNational">[http://www.arlingtoncemetery.mil/VisitorInformation/MonumentMemorials/SpanAmerican.aspx "Spanish-American War Monument." Monuments and Memorials. Exploring the Cemetery. Visitor Information. Arlington National Cemetery. No date.] Accessed 2013-06-13.</ref>
With the design approved, the Spanish War Memorial Committee's attention turned toward the language to be inscribed on the memorial. Lyster and another Spanish War Memorial Committee member, Hortense Addison Batré,<ref>She was the wife of [[Mobile, Alabama]], stock broker, banker, and natural gas company executive Alfred Batré.</ref> visited the [[Pan-American Exposition]] in [[Buffalo, New York]], in the summer of 1901, and were impressed by the inscriptions written on the pediment above the main doorway of each exhibit hall. They learned that these were written by the [[poet]] [[Richard Watson Gilder]], editor of ''[[The Century Magazine]]''. Townsend was acquainted with Gilder, and Lyster and Batré asked Townsend to convince Gilder to provide language for the bronze tablet. Townsend met with Gilder, and after some initial resistance he agreed to write the inscription.<ref name="Dames30" />
===Dedication=== The monument was unveiled and dedicated on May 21, 1902. President [[Theodore Roosevelt]] permitted all civilian and military government employees to be excused at noon so that they could attend the dedication ceremony.<ref name="Spanish01">"Dedication of Monument." ''Washington Post''. May 15, 1902.</ref>
The day of the event, 150 representatives to the National Council of the National Society of Colonial Dames convened in Washington, D.C., to conduct the business of the society before adjourning in the afternoon to attend the dedication at Arlington National Cemetery.<ref>"Colonial Dames Convene." ''Washington Post''. May 21, 1902.</ref>
The 4:30 P.M. dedication ceremony was overseen by [[Major general (United States)|Major General]] [[John R. Brooke]], commander of the U.S. Army's [[Department of the East]].<ref name="Spanish01" /><ref name="ToWar">"To Spanish War Soldiers." ''Washington Post''. May 20, 1902.</ref> Nearly 1,000 members of the [[United Spanish War Veterans|Spanish War Veterans]]—led by Lee M. Lipscomb, their national commander<ref name="Fame" />—mustered at 6th and E Streets NW and marched to the cemetery.<ref name="Fame" /><ref name="Spanish01" /> Attending the ceremony were a [[Battalion#United States Army|battalion]] from the [[United States Army Corps of Engineers|Corps of Engineers]] and a battalion of [[Field Artillery Branch (United States)|Light Artillery]] (each of which included a [[Military band|band]]).<ref name="ToWar" /> A battalion of [[United States Marines]] from the [[Washington Navy Yard]] and four [[Company (military unit)#Army|troop]] of [[cavalry]] from Fort Myer also participated.<ref name="Fame" /> Commanding the battalions were [[Captain (United States)|Captain]] James T. Dean, [[10th Infantry Regiment (United States)|10th Infantry]], and Captains Leroy S. Lyon and Edwin Landon, Light Artillery Corps.<ref name="ToWar" /> Dignitaries in attendance included President [[Theodore Roosevelt]], Secretary of War Elihu Root, [[Cabinet of the United States|Cabinet]] secretary [[George B. Cortelyou]], [[Lieutenant general (United States)|Lieutenant General]] [[John Schofield]] (retired [[Commanding General of the United States Army|Commanding General of the U.S. Army]]), and Lieutenant General [[Nelson A. Miles]] (incumbent Commanding General of the U.S. Army).<ref name="Fame" /> The bands played the "Dead March" (a [[dirge]]) from the [[oratorio]] ''[[Saul (Handel)|Saul]]'', and a 40-person [[choir]] from [[St. John's Episcopal Church, Lafayette Square (Washington, D.C.)|St. John's Episcopal Church]] sang "[[Onward, Christian Soldiers]]". [[Priesthood (Catholic Church)|Father]] T. S. Dolan of [[St. Patrick's Catholic Church (Washington, D.C.)|St. Patrick's Catholic Church]] provided the [[invocation]].<ref name="ToWar" /> [[Episcopal Diocese of Washington|Episcopal]] [[Bishop#Catholic Church, Orthodox churches and Anglican churches|Bishop]] [[Henry Y. Satterlee]] read the [[Episcopal Church (United States)|Episcopal]] funeral service for the dead, and then the audience sang "[[My Country, 'Tis of Thee]]".<ref name="Fame" /> Mrs. Townsend of the National Society of Colonial Dames spoke briefly, and then the shroud was pulled from the monument. After a brief viewing by dignitaries, President Roosevelt addressed the crowd. "[[The Star-Spangled Banner]]" was sung, and then Bishop Saterlee gave the [[benediction]].<ref name="Fame" /> The bands played "[[Nearer, My God, to Thee]]" as the audience dispersed.<ref name="ToWar" />
==About the memorial== [[File:Spanish-American War Memorial - eagle globe capital - Arlington National Cemetery - 2011.JPG|thumb|The eagle and sphere atop the capital at the Spanish–American War Memorial.]] The Spanish–American War Memorial consists of a [[column]] of gray granite {{convert|54|ft|m}} high<ref name="Fame" /> quarried in [[Barre (city), Vermont|Barre, Vermont]].<ref name="ArlingtonNational" /> Atop the column is a bronze eagle with outstretched wings,<ref name="Fame" /> facing west. The eagle is mounted on a granite [[globe]], which was quarried in [[Quincy, Massachusetts]].<ref name="ArlingtonNational" /> A band decorated with 13 stars (representing the original [[Thirteen Colonies]]) is carved in [[Relief#High relief|high relief]] on the globe.<ref name="Fame" /> The globe stands on a square base. The base stands atop a [[Corinthian order|Corinthian]] [[Capital (architecture)|capital]] which crowns the column.<ref>Federal Writers' Project, p. 609.</ref>
The column rests upon a tall [[plinth]] with a square cross-section. Around the top of the plinth are bronze stars {{convert|5|in|cm}} across. There are 11 stars on each of the four sides, for a total of 44 stars.<ref name="ArlingtonNational" /> A bronze tablet affixed to the front (west face) of the memorial contains the following language:<ref name="Fame" />
:To the soldiers and sailors of the United States who gave up their lives for their country in the war of 1898–99 with Spain this monument is dedicated in sorrow, gratitude, and pride by the National Society of Colonial Dames of America in the name of all the women of the nation. 1902.<ref>Note that the tablet incorrectly says that the Spanish–American War lasted into 1899.</ref>
The plinth stands on a larger square base, which sits atop a foundation set in the earth. On each corner of the foundation is a polished black granite sphere {{convert|18|in|cm}} in diameter.<ref name="ArlingtonNational" />
The total cost of the monument was $9,000 (${{formatnum:{{inflation|US|9000|1904}}}} in {{CURRENTYEAR}} dollars).<ref name="Fame" />
At the rear of the monument across Lawton Drive is a flagstone terrace. Four cannon, mounted on low brick pillars capped with concrete, stand on the eastern edge of this terrace. The guns point east. The inner two guns are larger and more modern, and were taken from the Spanish Navy armored cruisers ''Vizcaya'' and ''Infanta Maria Teresa''.<ref name="Independent" /><ref name="Fame" /> The two outer guns are smaller and made of bronze, and likely were captured from the Spanish coastal battery Castillo de San Pedro de la Roca at Sevilla near Santiago de Cuba.<ref name="Fame" /><ref name="NoMemorial" />
The memorial is notable because it was the first national memorial erected by a national society of women.<ref name="BostonEvening" /><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=CI0eAQAAMAAJ&dq=%22Spanish-American%20War%20Memorial%22%20Arlington&pg=RA2-PA55#v=onepage&q&f=false Laird, Gertrude S.J. "The National Society of Colonial Dames." ''The Vermonter.'' p. 55.] Accessed 2013-06-12.</ref> The ''[[Boston Evening Transcript]]'' criticized the memorial for being too plain for the magnificent site. It editorialized that the society should have taken time to collect more money, and built a more elaborate memorial. The newspaper expressed its hope that the Army would place no other memorials near it.<ref name="BostonEvening" />
===Second bronze tablet=== The National Society of Colonial Dames was given permission to add a second bronze tablet to the rear of the memorial in 1964. The {{convert|3|ft|6|in|m|adj=on}} square tablet was placed on the memorial on October 11, 1964. It reads:<ref name="ArlingtonNational" />
:To The Glory Of God And :In Grateful Remembrance :Of The Men And Women Of :The Armed Forces Who In :This Century Gave Their :Lives For Our Country :That Freedom Might Live :<nowiki>* * *</nowiki> :This Tablet Is Dedicated By The :National Society Of The Colonial Dames :Of America :October 11, 1964<ref>Note that the tablet incorrectly says that women served in the American armed forces. Although civilian women were used as contract nurses, federal law specifically excluded them from the armed forces.</ref>
===Third bronze tablet=== [[File:Spanish-American War Memorial - bronze marker - Arlington National Cemetery - 2011.JPG|thumb|The third bronze tablet at the Spanish–American War memorial.]] The National Society of Colonial Dames placed a third bronze tablet at the memorial on October 19, 2008. This {{convert|12|by|8|in|cm|adj=on}} tablet has a small eagle, clutching arrows and olive branches, in high relief at the top. It is attached to a rough grey granite base {{convert|6|in|cm}} high, which is set into the earth on the far western side of the grassy plaza. It is inscribed with the words:
:In Honor of All :Who Serve Our Country :Dedicated October 19, 2008 :by :The National Society of Colonial Dames of America
==Memorial Record Book== When the Spanish War Memorial Committee's Committee on Estimates and Designs considered the nature of the memorial, it quickly realized that the number of dead was too numerous to list their names on a tablet. A memorial book listing the names of the dead was more appropriate, so the Spanish War Memorial Committee established a second subcommittee, the Record Book Committee, to produce this volume. Esther Gill Jackson of [[Maryland]] was appointed chair of this subcommittee. Rosa Wright Smith of Washington, D.C., the society's Assistant National Secretary, was assigned to aid her.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=82EUAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA2-PA59&dq=%22Colonial+Dames%22+arlington&hl=en&sa=X&ei=xq63Ubb1CMTE0AGWiICYCQ&ved=0CEAQ6AEwAzgU#v=onepage&q=memorial&f=false National Society of the Colonial Dames of America, 1904, p. 55-59.] Accessed 2013-06-12.</ref> Jackson sent hundreds of letters to state militia commanders, requesting complete lists of the name, rank, and home towns of those in state militia and volunteer regiments who died in the war. Complete lists of U.S. Army and U.S. Navy dead were obtained from General [[Henry Clarke Corbin]], [[List of Adjutants General of the U.S. Army|Adjutant General of the Army]], and Rear Admiral [[Presley Marion Rixey]], [[Surgeon General of the United States Navy|Surgeon General of the Navy]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=82EUAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA2-PA59&dq=%22Colonial+Dames%22+arlington&hl=en&sa=X&ei=xq63Ubb1CMTE0AGWiICYCQ&ved=0CEAQ6AEwAzgU#v=onepage&q=memorial&f=false National Society of the Colonial Dames of America, 1904, p. 56-57.] Accessed 2013-06-12.</ref>
The Record Book (also known as the "Book of Patriots") published by the society was lavish. Almost $760 (${{formatnum:{{inflation|US|760|1904}}}} in {{CURRENTYEAR}} dollars) was raised to produce it. The {{convert|16|by|11|in|cm|adj=on}} book had 6,480 lines of information on 324 pages. The chapter page for each state was ornamental, the information pages consisted of [[parchment]], and each line was hand-drawn in [[India ink]]. The book was covered in dark green [[Morocco leather|Levant Morocco leather]], and hand-bound by the Ruzicka Bindery of [[Baltimore]].<ref name="Dames58">[https://books.google.com/books?id=82EUAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA2-PA59&dq=%22Colonial+Dames%22+arlington&hl=en&sa=X&ei=xq63Ubb1CMTE0AGWiICYCQ&ved=0CEAQ6AEwAzgU#v=onepage&q=memorial&f=false National Society of the Colonial Dames of America, 1904, p. 58.] Accessed 2013-06-12.</ref>
The Record Book Committee decided that a book stand should also be designed, constructed, and donated to Arlington National Cemetery to permit display of the Record Book. Members of the subcommittee were asked to submit designs for the book stand, nine of which were received. In January 1904, the Record Book Committee chose a design submitted by Lois B. Cassatt of [[Pennsylvania]].<ref name="Dames58" /> A "Mr. Evans" of Philadelphia was the designer (i.e., Allen Evans, architect with the firm [[Furness & Evans]]. This firm designed Cheswold, the Cassatt summer home.)<ref>"Colonial Dames Meet," ''Pittsburgh Post'' (October 23, 1904), part 2, page 5</ref> The winning design consisted of a table on a brick pillar, to be placed in the basement of [[Arlington House, The Robert E. Lee Memorial|Arlington House]]. The book was to be kept in a lockable, fire-proof box. The U.S. government provided an inscription for the inside lid of the box.<ref>The inscription read: "This book contains the names of the Soldiers and Sailors of the United States who died during the War with Spain in 1898, irrespective of their place of burial. It is not a public record, but is presented as a Memorial by the National Society of the Colonial Dames of America."</ref> The table was intended to be of [[soapstone]] or other durable, beautiful material.<ref name="Dames59">[https://books.google.com/books?id=82EUAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA2-PA59&dq=%22Colonial+Dames%22+arlington&hl=en&sa=X&ei=xq63Ubb1CMTE0AGWiICYCQ&ved=0CEAQ6AEwAzgU#v=onepage&q=memorial&f=false National Society of the Colonial Dames of America, 1904, p. 59.] Accessed 2013-06-12.</ref>
The book stand was given to Arlington National Cemetery in 1904. Although designed to stand on the earth in the cellar of Arlington House, cemetery officials placed it on one of the wooden floors above. The book stand was so heavy that the floor sagged and required reinforcement. At the time, the building was not a [[house museum]] but rather contained the living quarters of the Superintendent of Arlington National Cemetery and office space for him and his staff.<ref name="ArlingtonNational" /> In 1929, the Record Book was transferred from Arlington House to [[Arlington Memorial Amphitheater]] when the main floor of the amphitheater became a Memorial Exhibit Hall displaying honors received by the unknown soldiers lying beneath the Tomb of the Unknowns. (It is not clear if it was put on display, or housed in the second-floor offices.)<ref>"Trophies to Be Moved in Arlington Cemetery." ''New York Times''. July 17, 1929.</ref> The cemetery offices moved into what is now the Old Administration Building in 1932, and the book stand was misplaced. Its whereabouts are not known as of 2013.<ref name="ArlingtonNational" />
